title: Integrative Biological Hydrogen Production: An Overview
abstract: Biological hydrogen (H2) production by dark and photo-fermentative organisms is a promising area of research for generating bioenergy. A large number of organisms have been widely studied for producing H2 from diverse feeds, both as pure and as mixed cultures. However, their H2 producing efficiencies have been found to vary (from 3 to 8 mol/mol hexose) with physiological conditions, type of organisms and composition of feed (starchy waste from sweet potato, wheat, cassava and algal biomass). The present review deals with the possibilities of enhancing H2 production by integrating metabolic pathways of different organisms-dark fermentative bacteria (from cattle dung, activated sludge, Caldicellulosiruptor, Clostridium, Enterobacter, Lactobacillus, and Vibrio) and photo-fermentative bacteria (such as Rhodobacter, Rhodobium and Rhodopseudomonas). The emphasis has been laid on systems which are driven by undefined dark-fermentative cultures in combination with pure photo-fermentative bacterial cultures using biowaste as feed. Such an integrative approach may prove suitable for commercial applications on a large scale.

motivations: Biological hydrogen production has varying efficiencies depending on the organism, feed, and physiological conditions, limiting its potential for bioenergy generation.
There is a need for more efficient and scalable methods for biological hydrogen production to make it commercially viable.
objectives: Enhance hydrogen production by integrating metabolic pathways of different organisms, specifically dark and photo-fermentative bacteria.
Explore the potential of using biowaste as feed for hydrogen production through an integrative approach.
methods: Investigate the combination of undefined dark-fermentative cultures with pure photo-fermentative bacterial cultures for hydrogen production.
Use biowaste, such as starchy waste from sweet potato, wheat, cassava, and algal biomass, as feed for hydrogen production.
results: Improve the efficiency of biological hydrogen production through an integrative approach.
Develop a scalable and commercially viable method for biological hydrogen production using biowaste as feed.
llama_json.research_subject: Integrative biological hydrogen production using dark and photo-fermentative organisms

motivations: Biological hydrogen production is a promising area for bioenergy generation, but efficiencies vary based on physiological conditions, organisms, and feed composition.
There is a need to enhance hydrogen production by integrating metabolic pathways of different organisms.
objectives: Review the possibilities of enhancing hydrogen production by integrating metabolic pathways of dark and photo-fermentative organisms.
Focus on systems driven by undefined dark-fermentative cultures in combination with pure photo-fermentative bacterial cultures using biowaste as feed.
methods: Review and analyze the hydrogen production efficiencies of various organisms under different physiological conditions and feed compositions.
Investigate the integration of metabolic pathways of dark and photo-fermentative organisms for enhanced hydrogen production.
results: Potential enhancement of hydrogen production through the integration of metabolic pathways of different organisms.
Identification of suitable systems for commercial applications on a large scale.
openai_json.research_subject: Enhancing biological hydrogen production through the integration of metabolic pathways

motivations: Current biological hydrogen production methods have limited efficiency, yielding only 3 to 8 mol H2/mol hexose depending on organisms and conditions.
There is a need to develop more efficient and commercially viable biological hydrogen production systems using diverse biowaste feeds.
objectives: Enhance biological hydrogen production efficiency by integrating metabolic pathways of dark and photo-fermentative organisms.
Develop integrated systems combining undefined dark-fermentative cultures with pure photo-fermentative bacterial cultures for commercial-scale applications.
methods: Review and analyze hydrogen production capabilities of various dark fermentative bacteria and photo-fermentative bacteria.
Examine integrated approaches combining dark and photo-fermentation processes using biowaste feeds.
results: Identified potential for enhanced hydrogen production through integration of dark and photo-fermentative pathways.
Demonstrated that integrated systems using biowaste feeds may be suitable for large-scale commercial applications.
anthropic_json.research_subject: Biological hydrogen production through integrated dark and photo-fermentation processes
